description: From Middle English claritee, from Old French clarté, from Latin clāritās, from clārus (“clear”); equivalent to clear +‎ -ity.

entries.meaning: The state or measure of being clear, either in appearance, thought or style; lucidity.
examples: The brilliant clarity of his argument could not be faulted.

entries.meaning: The ability to be easily understood.
examples: Lack of clarity on the part of the teacher will cause confusion among the students.
